title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:1, if I speak with the tongues of men and of angels but do not have charity, what do I become?
options: Sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal
questions.correctAnswer: Sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal
questions.explanation: The verse states that without charity, speaking with tongues of men and angels makes one become as sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 13:4 say charity is NOT?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:4 describes charity as not envying, vaunting not itself, and not being puffed up.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:3, what will profit nothing without charity?
options: Giving all goods to feed the poor and giving one's body to be burned
questions.correctAnswer: Giving all goods to feed the poor and giving one's body to be burned
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that even if you give all your goods to feed the poor and give your body to be burned, without charity it profits nothing.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of charity according to 1 Corinthians 13:5?
questions.explanation: The verse states charity does not behave unseemly, does not seek her own, is not easily provoked, and thinks no evil.

questions.question: What does charity rejoice in according to 1 Corinthians 13:6?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:6 states that charity rejoices not in iniquity but rejoices in the truth.

questions.question: What does charity bear, believe, hope, and endure according to 1 Corinthians 13:7?
questions.explanation: The verse says charity beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:8, which of these never fails?
questions.explanation: The verse explains that charity never faileth, but prophecies, tongues, and knowledge shall fail or vanish away.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 13:9 says that we know everything perfectly.
questions.explanation: The verse states we know in part and prophesy in part, meaning our knowledge is incomplete.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:10, what shall happen when that which is perfect comes?
options: That which is in part shall be done away
questions.correctAnswer: That which is in part shall be done away
questions.explanation: The verse states that when the perfect comes, the partial will be done away.

questions.question: When did Paul say he put away childish things according to 1 Corinthians 13:11?
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that when he became a man, he put away childish things.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:12, how do we see now compared to then?
options: Through a glass, darkly; then face to face
With perfect clarity now and then
Face to face now and then
Through a mirror now and then
questions.correctAnswer: Through a glass, darkly; then face to face
questions.explanation: The verse compares our current imperfect knowledge as seeing through a dark glass, but in the future, we shall see face to face.

questions.question: Which three abide according to 1 Corinthians 13:13?
questions.explanation: The verse states that faith, hope, and charity abide, with the greatest being charity.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 13:2 says that having all faith to remove mountains is enough without charity.
questions.explanation: The verse says that even if you have all faith to remove mountains without charity you are nothing.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 13:7, charity endures all things.
questions.explanation: The verse states charity endureth all things, confirming the truth of the statement.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Corinthians 13:1: 'Though I speak with the tongues of men and of _______, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal.'
questions.explanation: The verse specifically mentions speaking with the tongues of men and of angels.

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of jealousy and pride. Based on 1 Corinthians 13, what biblical truth would you share about love's attitude?
options: Love is patient and kind, and does not envy or boast
Love is quick to anger and seeks its own
Love is easily provoked and thinks evil
questions.correctAnswer: Love is patient and kind, and does not envy or boast
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:4-5 teaches that love (charity) suffers long, is kind, does not envy, and does not boast or act proudly. These attitudes counter jealousy and pride.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 13 describe the importance of love compared to other spiritual gifts like prophecy or knowledge?
options: Without love, spiritual gifts profit nothing
Spiritual gifts are more important than love
Love is only necessary when gifts fail
questions.correctAnswer: Without love, spiritual gifts profit nothing
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 show that without charity (love), speaking in tongues, prophecy, knowledge, faith, and sacrifice profit nothing. Love is foundational to the value of gifts.

questions.question: A church member is giving generously but feels unappreciated. What does 1 Corinthians 13 teach about the role of love in acts of giving?
options: Giving impresses others more than love does
Love is unnecessary if giving is large
Generosity replaces the need for love
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:3 emphasizes that even giving all goods to feed the poor without love profits nothing, highlighting love's essential role in generosity.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 13 instruct believers to respond when they face provocation or wrongdoing from others?
options: Love is not easily provoked and does not think evil
Love always keeps a record of wrongs
questions.correctAnswer: Love is not easily provoked and does not think evil
questions.explanation: Verse 5 teaches that love is not easily provoked and thinks no evil, indicating a gentle and forgiving attitude in difficult circumstances.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their prayer language and prophecy seem to fade in importance. What encouragement does 1 Corinthians 13 offer?
options: Love never fails, but prophecies and tongues will cease
Spiritual gifts are permanent and never fade
Faith is more important than love
questions.correctAnswer: Love never fails, but prophecies and tongues will cease
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:8 explains that love never fails, while prophecies, tongues, and knowledge will pass away, showing the eternal value of love.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach us about the maturity process in faith and understanding?
options: When we mature, we put away childish things
Faith and understanding remain childish forever
Maturity is not important in Christian life
Childish thoughts are better than adult understanding
questions.correctAnswer: When we mature, we put away childish things
questions.explanation: Verse 11 uses the analogy of growing from childhood to adulthood, putting away childish ways as a metaphor for spiritual maturity.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 13 say about how we currently know God compared to the future?
options: Now we see through a glass darkly, but then face to face
We will never know God fully
Knowing God is only through prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: Now we see through a glass darkly, but then face to face
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches that our present knowledge is partial and unclear, but in the future we will know fully, face to face.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13, which of the following virtues remains forever?
options: Faith, hope, and love, with love being the greatest
questions.correctAnswer: Faith, hope, and love, with love being the greatest
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states that faith, hope, and charity (love) abide, and the greatest of these is love, emphasizing its enduring importance.

questions.question: A Christian is trying to live humbly and avoid selfishness. What does 1 Corinthians 13 teach about love's behavior?
options: Love does not seek its own and is not proud
Love is quick to boast about itself
Love behaves unseemly to get attention
questions.correctAnswer: Love does not seek its own and is not proud
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:5 explains that love does not seek its own and is not arrogant or rude, promoting humility and selflessness.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 13 describe love's response to truth and evil?
options: Love rejoices with the truth and not in iniquity
questions.correctAnswer: Love rejoices with the truth and not in iniquity
questions.explanation: Verse 6 teaches that love does not rejoice in wrongdoing but rejoices with the truth, encouraging integrity and righteousness.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 13 say about love's perseverance through challenges?
options: Love bears, believes, hopes, and endures all things
Love only lasts when life is easy
questions.correctAnswer: Love bears, believes, hopes, and endures all things
questions.explanation: Verse 7 describes love as bearing all things, believing all things, hoping all things, and enduring all things, highlighting steadfastness.

questions.question: A believer is confused about spiritual knowledge and prophecy. How does 1 Corinthians 13 explain their present status?
options: We know in part and prophesy in part
questions.correctAnswer: We know in part and prophesy in part
questions.explanation: Verse 9 teaches that our current knowledge and prophecy are partial, pointing to the need for patience in spiritual growth.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 13, love is more important than faith and hope.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:13 clearly states that among faith, hope, and love, the greatest is love, highlighting its supreme importance.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 13 teaches that without love, even the greatest sacrifices have value.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 explain that without love, even giving all goods or sacrificing the body profits nothing, showing love's essential role.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not ________, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal."
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states that without charity (love), speaking in tongues is like a noisy gong, emphasizing love's necessity.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 13.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 13:1, Paul compares speaking in tongues without charity to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Paul states that speaking in tongues without charity is like becoming sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal, emphasizing the emptiness of speech without love.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:4, which of the following is NOT a characteristic of charity?
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states charity suffereth long, is kind, envieth not, vaunteth not itself, and verse 5 clarifies it is not easily provoked, indicating 'is easily provoked' is incorrect.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 1 Corinthians 13:7: Charity ______ all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly says 'Beareth all things' describing charity’s enduring nature.

questions.question: What does Paul indicate will happen to prophecies, tongues, and knowledge according to 1 Corinthians 13:8?
options: They shall fail, cease, and vanish away respectively
They are more important than charity
They are permanent gifts from God
questions.correctAnswer: They shall fail, cease, and vanish away respectively
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts charity, which never fails, with prophecies, tongues, and knowledge which will fail, cease, and vanish away.

questions.question: In the context of 1 Corinthians 13:10, 'that which is perfect' most likely refers to:
options: The coming of Christ and full revelation
The end of the Corinthian church
questions.correctAnswer: The coming of Christ and full revelation
questions.explanation: Scholars interpret 'that which is perfect' as the complete revelation in Christ, contrasting with partial knowledge and prophecy.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 13:3, giving all one’s goods to feed the poor without charity is profitable.
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that even giving all goods to feed the poor profits nothing without charity.

questions.question: How does Paul’s use of child-to-man imagery in 1 Corinthians 13:11 illustrate spiritual maturity?
options: It shows a rejection of innocence
It depicts putting away childish ways for full understanding
It explains the growth of physical strength
It emphasizes the importance of childhood faith
questions.correctAnswer: It depicts putting away childish ways for full understanding
questions.explanation: Paul uses the analogy of growing from childhood to manhood to illustrate moving from partial to full spiritual understanding.

questions.question: Which Old Testament concept is echoed in 1 Corinthians 13:12’s phrase 'now we see through a glass, darkly'?
options: The pillar of cloud by day (Exodus 13)
questions.explanation: The metaphor of seeing 'through a glass, darkly' alludes to Moses’ veiled face, symbolizing incomplete understanding.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 to describe charity?
questions.explanation: These verses use parallelism by listing contrasting characteristics that define charity’s nature.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:13, which of the following is declared the greatest?
questions.explanation: Paul concludes that among faith, hope, and charity, charity (love) is the greatest enduring virtue.

questions.question: In the cultural context of first-century Corinth, why would Paul emphasize charity over spiritual gifts as in 1 Corinthians 13:1-3?
options: Because Corinth valued social status over love
Because spiritual gifts were causing division without love
Because charity was a known pagan virtue
Because prophecy was forbidden in Corinth
questions.correctAnswer: Because spiritual gifts were causing division without love
questions.explanation: Paul addresses the Corinthian church where giftedness caused pride and division; he stresses charity as the unifying principle.

questions.question: How does the Greek term 'agape' translated as 'charity' in this chapter differ from other Greek words for love?
questions.explanation: 'Agape' is the highest form of love, self-giving and unconditional, distinct from 'eros' or 'philia'.

questions.question: What does Paul imply about the permanence of faith, hope, and charity in 1 Corinthians 13:13?
options: All three will fade away eventually
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes that faith and hope are temporary in comparison to the eternal nature of charity.

questions.question: 1 Corinthians 13:9 states 'For we know in part, and we prophesy in part.' This partial knowledge contrasts with which concept introduced later in the chapter?
options: The arrival of the perfect or complete knowledge
The cessation of all gifts immediately
The importance of prophecy over charity
questions.correctAnswer: The arrival of the perfect or complete knowledge
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clarifies that partial knowledge will be done away when the perfect comes, indicating full revelation.

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul’s phrase 'face to face' in 1 Corinthians 13:12 in biblical typology?
options: It alludes to direct communion with God in the eschaton
It references Moses meeting God on Mount Sinai
It symbolizes the end of prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: It alludes to direct communion with God in the eschaton
questions.explanation: 'Face to face' signifies perfect knowledge and direct encounter with God anticipated in the end times.

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13, what is the consequence of speaking with the tongues of men and angels without charity?
options: I am become as sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal
questions.correctAnswer: I am become as sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:1 teaches that without charity, even the gift of speaking in tongues is like noisy, meaningless sound. This aligns with Isaiah 29:13, Matthew 15:8, James 2:17, and 1 John 3:18 emphasizing the necessity of love in action and speech.

questions.question: What does Paul say about having the gift of prophecy, understanding all mysteries, and having all faith without charity?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:2 states that without charity, even great spiritual gifts and faith amount to nothing. This reflects the biblical theme that love is the greatest virtue (Romans 13:10; Galatians 5:6; 1 John 4:8; Matthew 22:37-40).

questions.question: How does charity behave according to 1 Corinthians 13:4?
questions.explanation: Verse 4 describes charity as patient and kind, contrasting sinful human traits found in Proverbs 14:29, James 1:19, Ephesians 4:2, and Colossians 3:12. Charity's nature reflects God's own long-suffering love (Exodus 34:6).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of charity as described in 1 Corinthians 13:5?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 13:5 explicitly states charity does NOT behave unseemly; it is honorable and selfless. This aligns with Philippians 4:8, Romans 12:10, 1 Peter 3:8, and Galatians 5:22-23 describing love's holy conduct.

questions.question: What does charity rejoice in, according to 1 Corinthians 13:6?
questions.explanation: Verse 6 contrasts rejoicing in truth with not rejoicing in iniquity, highlighting love's alignment with God's holiness and justice (Psalm 33:4; John 17:17; Proverbs 12:22; Zechariah 8:16).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:7, charity is described as bearing all things, believing all things, hoping all things, and what else?
questions.explanation: Verse 7 emphasizes charity's enduring nature amidst trials, consistent with Romans 5:5, James 1:12, Hebrews 12:1-2, and 1 Peter 4:8 teaching perseverance in love.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 13:8 say about the permanence of charity compared to prophecies, tongues, and knowledge?
options: Charity never faileth; prophecies, tongues, and knowledge shall cease
Prophecies and tongues last forever, charity fades
Knowledge is permanent, but charity is not
questions.correctAnswer: Charity never faileth; prophecies, tongues, and knowledge shall cease
questions.explanation: This verse teaches the eternal nature of love contrasted with the temporary gifts (Hebrews 13:8; Isaiah 40:8; John 13:34-35; 1 John 4:7-8). Love endures beyond spiritual gifts and knowledge.

questions.question: How does Paul describe our current knowledge and prophecy in 1 Corinthians 13:9?
options: We know and prophesy in part
We do not know or prophesy
questions.correctAnswer: We know and prophesy in part
questions.explanation: Verse 9 acknowledges the partial and incomplete nature of our present knowledge, echoing Job 42:3, Ecclesiastes 12:13, Proverbs 3:5, and 1 John 3:2 emphasizing God's full knowledge surpasses ours.

questions.question: What happens 'when that which is perfect is come,' according to 1 Corinthians 13:10?
options: That which is in part shall be done away
questions.correctAnswer: That which is in part shall be done away
questions.explanation: The coming of perfection (often understood as the eschaton or full revelation in Christ) will render partial knowledge obsolete, consistent with Daniel 12:4, Hebrews 11:1, Revelation 21:3-4, and John 14:3.

questions.question: What analogy does Paul use in 1 Corinthians 13:11 to describe the transition from partial understanding to maturity?
options: When I was a child, I spake as a child, but when I became a man, I put away childish things
As a seed grows into a tree
As a shepherd leads his sheep
questions.correctAnswer: When I was a child, I spake as a child, but when I became a man, I put away childish things
questions.explanation: Verse 11 uses childhood and adulthood to illustrate spiritual growth and maturity, resonating with Ephesians 4:13-15, Hebrews 5:12-14, Proverbs 4:7, and Colossians 1:28.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 13:12 describe our current perception of God compared to the future?
options: Now we see through a glass, darkly; then face to face
We see God always face to face
questions.correctAnswer: Now we see through a glass, darkly; then face to face
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts current partial and obscure knowledge with future direct and full knowledge, aligning with Job 19:26, Exodus 33:20, John 1:18, and Revelation 22:4.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 13:13, which of these is considered the greatest?
questions.explanation: Verse 13 affirms that among faith, hope, and charity (love), charity is the greatest virtue, consistent with Romans 13:10, Galatians 5:6, 1 John 4:8, and Matthew 22:37-40.

questions.question: What does Paul imply about the value of giving all goods to feed the poor without charity in 1 Corinthians 13:3?
questions.explanation: Verse 3 teaches that even sacrificial giving and self-denial are worthless without love, echoing Mark 12:33, Luke 21:1-4, Proverbs 21:3, and Matthew 6:1-4 emphasizing the heart's intention in righteousness.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a way charity is described as NOT doing in 1 Corinthians 13:4-5?
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 state charity "seeketh not her own" (not selfish), not specifically 'seeks its own glory.' This distinction is important as love is humble, unlike selfish ambition (Philippians 2:3; James 3:16; Proverbs 16:18; Matthew 23:12).

questions.question: What spiritual gifts are mentioned in 1 Corinthians 13:8 as eventually failing or ceasing?
questions.explanation: Verse 8 specifies these gifts as temporary, contrasting with the permanence of love, in line with Joel 2:28, Acts 2:17-18, and Hebrews 2:3-4 emphasizing the temporary nature of miraculous gifts.
